DESCRIPTION DESCRIPTION
udev supplies the system software with device events, manages permis sions of device nodes and may create additional symlinks in the /dev direct ory, or renames network interfaces. The kernel usually just assigns udev supplies the system software with device events, manages permis sions of device nodes and may create additional symlinks in the /dev direct ory, or renames network interfaces. The kernel usually just assigns
unpredictable device names based on the order of discovery. Meaningf ul symlinks or network device names provide a way to reliably identify devi ces based on their properties or current configuration. unpredictable device names based on the order of discovery. Meaningf ul symlinks or network device names provide a way to reliably identify devi ces based on their properties or current configuration.
The udev daemon, udevd(8), receives device uevents directly from the kernel whenever a device is added or removed from the system, or it change s its state. When udev receives a device event, it matches its configured s et of The udev daemon, udevd(8), receives device uevents directly from the kernel whenever a device is added or removed from the system, or it change s its state. When udev receives a device event, it matches its configured s et of
rules against various device attributes to identify the device. Rule s that match may provide additional device information to be stored in the udev database or to be used to create meaningful symlink names. rules against various device attributes to identify the device. Rule s that match may provide additional device information to be stored in the udev database or to be used to create meaningful symlink names.
All device information udev processes is stored in the udev database and sent out to possible event subscribers. Access to all stored data and the event sources is provided by the library libudev. All device information udev processes is stored in the udev database and sent out to possible event subscribers. Access to all stored data and the event sources is provided by the library libudev.
CONFIGURATION CONFIGURATION
udev configuration files are placed in /etc/udev/ and /lib/udev/. Al l empty lines or lines beginning with '#' are ignored. udev configuration files are placed in /etc/udev and /usr/lib/udev. All empty lines or lines beginning with '#' are ignored.
Configuration file Configuration file
udev expects its main configuration file at /etc/udev/udev.conf. It consists of a set of variables allowing the user to override default udev v alues. The following variables can be set: udev expects its main configuration file at /etc/udev/udev.conf. It consists of a set of variables allowing the user to override default udev v alues. The following variables can be set:
udev_root udev_root
Specifies where to place the device nodes in the filesystem. The default value is /dev. Specifies where to place the device nodes in the filesystem. The default value is /dev.
udev_log udev_log
The logging priority. Valid values are the numerical syslog prio rities or their textual representations: err, info and debug. The logging priority. Valid values are the numerical syslog prio rities or their textual representations: err, info and debug.

Every line in the rules file contains at least one key-value pair. T here are two kind of keys: match and assignment. A matching rule may rename a network interface, add symlinks pointin g to the device node, or run a specified program as part of the event handl ing. A matching rule may rename a network interface, add symlinks pointin g to the device node, or run a specified program as part of the event handl ing.
A rule consists of a comma-separated list of one or more key-value p airs. Each key has a distinct operation, depending on the used operator. [] []
Matches any single character specified within the brackets. For example, the pattern string 'tty[SR]' would match either 'ttyS' or 'ttyR'. Ranges are also supported via the '-' character. For example, to match on t he Matches any single character specified within the brackets. For example, the pattern string 'tty[SR]' would match either 'ttyS' or 'ttyR'. Ranges are also supported via the '-' character. For example, to match on t he
range of all digits, the pattern [0-9] could be used. If the fir st character following the '[' is a '!', any characters not enclosed are ma tched. range of all digits, the pattern [0-9] could be used. If the fir st character following the '[' is a '!', any characters not enclosed are ma tched.

NAME NAME
What a network interface should be named. The name to use for a network interface. The name of a device no
de can not be changed by udev, only additional symlinks can be created.
Also, as a temporary workaround, this is what a device node shou
ld be named; usually the kernel provides the defined node name or creates a
nd removes the node before udev even receives any event. Changing the node
name
from the kernel's default creates inconsistencies and is not sup
ported. If the kernel and NAME specify different names, an error is logged.
udev is only expected to handle device node permissions and to create
additional symlinks, not to change kernel-provided device node n
ames. Instead of renaming a device node, SYMLINK should be used. However, s
ymlink names must never conflict with device node names, as that would resu
lt in
unpredictable behavior.

link_priority=value link_priority=value
Specify the priority of the created symlinks. Devices with h igher priorities overwrite existing symlinks of other devices. The default is 0. Specify the priority of the created symlinks. Devices with h igher priorities overwrite existing symlinks of other devices. The default is 0.
